text: today's recipe is kind of special
because it reminds me of my childhood
it's a rhubarb custard pie rhubarb is
one of my favorites and when I was
younger my mom used to make this rhubarb
custard pie from the joy of cooking
which is still one of my favorite
resources for finding bit of great
cooking methods it was a rhubarb with
custard so I decided that we should make
one like that here and we did and this
is the result I'm starting off with a
disc of peppers a that I made and rolled
out so put it into your pie plate have
your oven preheating at 375 degrees trim
the edges to about an inch doesn't have
to be perfect because you're going to
fold the edges under creating a double
edge boom fold under you can crimp this
if you want to you can decorate it
however you want I'm going to press down
the edges with the tines of a fork
that's a nice simple way to finish your
pie the key to success for this rhubarb
pie is to blind bake your crust before
you add your custard filling so normally
I would poke holes in the bottom of this
to make sure that it doesn't puff up
when I'm blind baking it but because I'm
putting a custard in I get a little
paranoid that maybe some of the custard
will seep through so I'm not doing it it
might puff a little but it'll be okay
you know what Thomas does I want to tell
you this because it's really cool and I
never do it is parchment into a little
ball and then he unfolds it and he says
that that makes it go into the corners
better fill with pie weights I like to
use beans because then you can buy a
couple of bags and you can really really
fill your crust with a lot of beans
which holds the sides up really well it
does make it so that it takes slightly
longer to blind-bake than you might be
used to but I think it's well worth the
time so get this into a 375 degree oven
and you want to bake it until the edges
are set and like a golden brown then
you're going to remove all of this and
bake it until the bottom is golden that
usually takes about five to eight more
minutes
the filling one-pound of rhubarb cut in
half inch pieces toss that with a
quarter cup of your sugar one I sort of
start drawing out the juices and get it
going before you add it to the filling
and prease we defy it because if you
just put this into the custard which is
sweetened it's not going to be quite
sweet enough because rhubarb is really
tangy so let that sit you can let it sit
for about ten minutes while you make
your filling what you want to do is
combine everything in a bowl this is
half a stick of butter about four
tablespoons quarter cup of heavy cream
just a little richness two large eggs I
like to whisk at this point just to get
the eggs broken down and then to that
add another one and a quarter cups of
sugar rhubarb is not a fruit at all and
very not sweet at all
so you need to really make sure that
it's sweetened then add a third of a cup
of all-purpose flour so you have eggs in
this custard for thickening that you
also have flour both important here
because also Roux bar well it's also not
sweet is also quite watery so you need
the addition of the flour in here to
make sure that your custard thickens
nicely now you're ready to fill your pie
here's the crust that I baked now you're
gonna notice it is slightly puffed in
the center that's okay
but it's nice and gold and completely
dry you can actually lift it up and
that's what I like when I'm making a
custard pie I really want the crust to
be completely baked
because I've found that once you add
custard to a pie crust
it doesn't really bake anymore put it
back in the oven it bakes for a fifty
minutes an hour and nothing happens to
the crust so if it starts out soggy it's
going to end up soggy so start it out
crisp and it'll end up crisp that's my
pie philosophy and I'm sticking to it
scrape your custard into your blind
baked shell and then scatter your
rhubarb over the top have the oven still
at 375 so you can leave your oven at
your 375 from blind baking
just don't let it overflow get it into
the oven what you want to do is bake
this until it's set in the center but
just like slightly a little bit wobbly
that'll take 50 minutes to 1 hour when
it's done you're going to want to take
it out and let it cool on wire rack for
about an hour and then refrigerate it
until you're ready to eat then you can
cut into it and enjoy serve yourself a
slice and then get eating let's say mmm
it's tangy goodness you guys make
rhubarb custard pie and then write me a
thank-you note I know you're gonna love
it
